input.question: Which of the following has proved helpful in preserving pollen as fossils?

response.explanation: Sporopollenin cannot be degraded by enzymes, strong acids, or alkali, therefore it is helpful in preserving pollen as fossils.

input.question: It is much easier for a small animal to run uphill than for a large animal, because

options.a: it is easier to carry a small body weight.
options.b: smaller animals have a higher metabolic rate.
options.c: small animals have a lower O2 requirement.
options.d: the efficiency of muscles in large animals is less than in the small animals.

response.explanation: Basal metabolic rate is inversely proportional to body size, so smaller animals have a higher metabolic rate. Hence, the production of energy is more.

input.question: Which one of the following aspects is an exclusive characteristic of living things?

options.a: Isolated metabolic reactions occur in vitro
options.b: Increase in mass from inside only
options.c: Perception of events happening in the environment and their memory
options.d: Increase in mass by accumulation of material both on surface as well as internally.

response.explanation: All living things have an ability to respond to their environment (called stimulation or responsiveness) and possess memory.

input.question: Biological organisation starts with

response.explanation: Biological organisms start with the submicroscopic molecular level like viruses, bacteria, etc.

input.question: The living organisms can be unexceptionally distinguished from the non-living things on the basis of their ability for

options.a: interaction with the environment and progressive evolution

response.explanation: Among the options, reproduction is the only difference that differentiates living beings from non-living things without any exception.

input.question: Angiosperms have dominated the land flora primarily because of their

options.a: power of adaptability in diverse habitat
options.b: property of producing large number of seeds

response.explanation: Angiosperms have adapted themselves to all kinds of habitatsâ€”terrestrial, aquatic, tropical, deciduous, and alpine. Self-pollination is seen in very few angiosperms. Production of a large number of seeds ensures that at least some will germinate. Not all plants have been domesticated by man.

input.question: Organisms which obtain energy by the oxidation of reduced inorganic compounds are called

response.explanation: The organisms obtaining energy by chemical reactions independent of light are called chemotrophs. When the reductants obtained from the environment are in inorganic form, the organisms are called chemoautotrophs. If they are organic, then the organisms are chemoheterotrophs.

input.question: What is true for photolithotrops?

options.a: Obtain energy from radiations and hydrogen from organic compounds
options.b: Obtain energy from radiations and hydrogen from inorganic compounds

response.explanation: Photolithotrophs manufacture their own organic nutrients from inorganic raw materials $(\mathrm{H}_2, \mathrm{O}_2)$ with the help of radiation energy. Examples include purple bacteria, green bacteria, and Cyanobacteria. Purple and green bacteria oxidize sulfide, sulfur, sulfite, iron or hydrogen.

input.question: First life on earth was

response.explanation: First life on earth was chemoheterotroph. These were formed in the environment of the sea having abundant organic molecules. They absorbed the organic materials for the sake of nutrition and hence were chemoheterotrophs.

input.question: The most important feature of all living systems is to

options.d: utilize solar energy for metabolic activities

response.explanation: Replication of the genetic information causes transfer of genetic information from one generation to the next.

input.question: The book Genera Plantarum was written by

response.explanation: Bentham & Hooker wrote the book Genera Plantarum. This work was begun in 1862 and concluded in 1883 in collaboration with Sir Joseph Dalton Hooker.

input.question: Study of fossils is

response.explanation: Palaentology is the branch of zoology concerned with the study of fossils.

input.question: Homeostasis is organism's

options.a: tendency to change with change in environment
options.d: plants and animal extracts used in homeopathy

response.explanation: Homeostasis is the property of all living beings, which is a self-regulatory mechanism of maintaining favorable internal conditions for uninterrupted chemical reactions in the living system despite the changes in the external environment. E.g., in winter the skin contracts to conserve body heat.

input.question: Employment of hereditary principles in the improvement of human race is

response.explanation: Eugenics is the science that deals with factors (such as principles of genetics) related to the improvement of the human race. Improvement of race is positive eugenics and if factors are impaired, then it is negative eugenics. Ethnology is the study of different races of mankind, their distribution, relationship, and activities. Euphenics is the study of body functions and treatment of heredity defects through medical means, i.e., genetic engineering. Euthenics is the science which improves the condition of life and the environment of human being.

input.question: Static concept of species was put forward by

response.explanation: Carolus Linnaeus introduced the Binomial System of Nomenclature in his book Species Plantarum (1753). He said that there can be variation within species, but they do not change from one species to another.

input.question: Which of the following is against the rules of ICBN?

options.a: Generic and specific names should be written starting with small letters.
options.b: Hand written scientific names should be underlined.
options.c: Every species should have a generic name and a specific epithet.
options.d: Scientific names are in Latin and should be italized.

response.explanation: The first word denoting the genus starts with a capital letter while the specific epithet starts with a small letter. In plant nomenclature (ICBN), tautonyms are not valid (i.e., generic name and specific name should not be the same in plants), but tautonyms are valid for animal nomenclature (ICZN).

input.question: Select the correctly written scientific name of Mango which was first described by Carolus Linnaeus:

response.explanation: According to the rules of binomial nomenclature, the correctly written scientific name of mango is Mangifera indica Linn. Mangifera indicates the 'genus' while indica represents a particular species or 'specific epithet' and Linn indicates the Biologist Linnaeus who first described the species of mango.

input.question: Nomenclature is governed by certain universal rules. Which one of the following is contrary to the rules of nomenclature?

options.a: Biological names can be written in any language
options.b: The first word in a biological name represents the genus name, and the second is a specific epithet
options.c: The names are written in Latin and are italicised
options.d: When written by hand, the names are to be underlined

response.explanation: Binomial nomenclature is a formal system of naming species of living things by giving each a name composed of two parts, both of which use Latin grammatical forms, although they can be based on words from other languages.

input.question: The common characteristics between tomato and potato will be maximum at the level of their

response.explanation: Families are characterised on the basis of both vegetative and reproductive features of plant species. Tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum) and potato (Solanum tuberosum) belong to the same family Solanaceae.

input.question: Which one of the following organisms is scientifically correctly named, correctly printed according to the International Rules of Nomenclature and correctly described?

options.a: Musca domestica - The common house lizard, a reptile.
options.b: Plasmodium falciparum - A protozoan pathogen causing the most serious type of malaria.
options.c: Felis tigris - The Indian tiger, well protected in Gir forests.
options.d: E.coli - Full name Entamoeba coli, a commonly occurring bacterium in human intestine.

response.explanation: Plasmodium falciparum is a protozoan pathogen that causes the most serious type of malaria (falciparum malaria). Musca domestica is a house fly, an insect belonging to phylum Arthropoda. Felis tigris (the Bengal tiger) is well protected in Sundarbans (tiger reserve). E.coli's full name is Escherichia coli, a commonly occurring bacterium in the human intestine.

input.question: Which one of the following animals is correctly matched with its particular named taxonomic category?

response.explanation: The species name of the Tiger is tigris (Genus: Panthera).

input.question: ICBN stands for

response.explanation: ICBN stands for International Code of Botanical Nomenclature. It is one of the codes of nomenclature which is independent of zoological and bacteriological nomenclature. The code applies equally to names of taxonomic groups treated as plants.

input.question: Phenetic classification is based on

options.b: the ancestral lineage of existing organisms

response.explanation: Phenetic classification is based upon the observable characteristics of an organism. Phylogenetic system of classification is a system indicating the evolutionary or phylogenetic relationship of organisms.

input.question: Biosystematics aims at

options.a: identification and arrangement of organisms on the basis of their cytological characteristics
options.b: the classification of organisms based on broad morphological characters
options.c: delimiting various taxa of organisms and establishing their relationships
options.d: the classification of organisms based on their evolutionary history and establishing their phylogeny on the totality of various parameters from all fields of studies

response.explanation: Biosystematics is the study of the diversity of organisms and all their comparative and evolutionary relationships. It is the science through which life forms are discovered, identified, described, named, classified, and catalogued, with their diversity, life histories, living habits, roles in an ecosystem, and spatial and geographical distributions recorded.

input.question: Species are considered as

options.a: real units of classification devised by taxonomists
options.d: artificial concept of human mind which cannot be defined in absolute terms

response.explanation: Species is the lowest or basic taxonomic category comprising of one or more natural populations of individuals that interbreed freely. While it is the basic unit (b), the question asks what they are considered, and the lowest unit of classification is a more precise description.

input.question: What is true for individuals of same species?

response.explanation: Individuals of the same species can interbreed. No two individuals share the same ecological niche.

input.question: The practical purpose of classification of living organisms is to

options.a: explain the origin of living organisms
options.b: trace the evolution of living organisms

response.explanation: Biological classification is the scientific arrangement of organisms in a hierarchical series of groups and subgroups on the basis of similarities and differences in their traits. It helps in building evolutionary pathways and in identifying new organisms.

input.question: A taxon is

options.d: a taxonomic group of any ranking

response.explanation: A taxon is a taxonomic group of any rank. E.g., Family, Genus, Species, etc.

input.question: Binomial nomenclature was introduced by

response.explanation: Binomial nomenclature, also called binominal nomenclature or binary nomenclature, is a formal system of naming species of living things by giving each a name composed of two parts, both of which use Latin grammatical forms.

input.question: Species is a

options.b: unit in the evolutionary history of a tree

response.explanation: Species is the basic unit of classification. It is defined as a group of natural population whose members can interbreed among themselves and are reproductively isolated from other such groups.

input.question: Binomial nomenclature consists of two words

response.explanation: Binomial nomenclature consists of two words: genus and species. The first word denotes the genus name, and the second word denotes the species name.

input.question: "Taxonomy without phylogeny is similar to bones without flesh" is the statement of

response.explanation: The statement was given by Armen Leonovich Takhtajan, a Soviet-Armenian botanist, one of the most important figures in 20th century plant evolution and systematics and biogeography.

input.question: Binomial nomenclature means

options.a: one name given by two scientists
options.b: one scientific name consisting of a generic and specific epithet
options.c: two names, one latinised, other of a person

response.explanation: Binomial nomenclature means the scientific name of any organism consists of a generic and a specific epithet. The generic name starts with a capital letter and the specific name with a small letter. Both the names are in Italics when printed, or underlined in manuscripts.

input.question: Linnaeus is credited with

response.explanation: Linnaeus is credited with introducing Binomial Nomenclature.

input.question: The term phylum was given by

response.explanation: Cuvier, the father of modern palaeontology, introduced the term "phylum." A phylum is a level of classification below kingdom and above class. Traditionally, in botany, the term division has been used instead of phylum, although the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants accepts the terms as equivalent.

input.question: Sequence of taxonomic categories is

options.a: Class-Phylum - Tribe - Order - Family - Genus - Species
options.c: Division-Class - Order - Family - Tribe - Genus - Species
options.d: Phylum-Order - Class - Tribe - Family - Genus - Species

response.explanation: The various obligate categories in hierarchical classification are Division $\rightarrow$ Class $\rightarrow$ Order $\rightarrow$ Family $\rightarrow$ Tribe $\rightarrow$ Genus $\rightarrow$ Species. (In zoology, Phylum is used instead of Division).

input.question: An important criterion for modern day classification is

response.explanation: Modern-day classification is new systematics or biosystematics which includes all the characteristics of organisms gathered from the study of different sections like physiology, ecology, anatomy, biochemistry, and cytology.

input.question: Linnaeus evolved a system of nomenclature called

response.explanation: A system for classification was developed by Carolus Linnaeus known as "Binomial nomenclature." This system provides organisms with appropriate and distinct names consisting of two words, the generic name and the specific epithet. The first scientific attempt to name the organism was polynomial nomenclature which consisted of a number of words.

input.question: Basic unit or smallest taxon of taxonomy/classification is

response.explanation: Species, the basic unit for understanding taxonomy, occupies a key position. It is defined as a dynamic genetically distinct group of organisms, which resemble each other in all respects and freely interbreed among themselves to produce fertile offsprings.

input.question: The term "New Systematics" was introduced by

response.explanation: The term "New Systematics" was coined by Julian Huxley (1940).

input.question: The contrasting characteristics generally in a pair used for identification of animals in Taxonomic Key are referred to as :

response.explanation: The keys are based on the set of contrasting characters in a pair known as a couplet.

input.question: Which one of the following is not a correct statement?

options.a: Botanical gardens have collection of living plants for reference.
options.b: A museum has collection of photographs of plants and animals
options.c: Key is taxonomic aid for identification of specimens.
options.d: Herbarium houses dried, pressed and preserved plant specimens.

response.explanation: Museums have collections of preserved plant and animal specimens for study and reference (e.g., in jars with preservative solutions or as dry specimens), not primarily photographs. Larger animals like birds and mammals are usually stuffed and preserved, and museums often have collections of skeletons.

input.question: Pick up the wrong statement

options.a: Protista have photosynthetic and heterotrophic modes of nutrition
options.c: Nuclear membrane is present in Monera
options.d: Cell wall is absent in Animalia

response.explanation: The kingdom Monera possesses unicellular organisms (e.g - bacteria) having no nuclear membrane.

input.question: Five kingdom system of classification suggested by R.H. Whittaker is not based on:

options.a: Presence or absence of a well defined nucleus.

response.explanation: Five kingdom system of classification was proposed by R.H. Whittaker (1969). The five kingdom classification is based on complexity of cell structure, complexity of organisms body, mode of obtaining nutrition, and phylogenetic relationships.

input.question: In the five-kingdom system of classification, which single kingdom out of the following can include blue green algae, nitrogen-fixing bacteria and methanogenic archaebacteria?

response.explanation: Monera is the prokaryotic kingdom that includes bacteria, blue green algae (cyanobacteria) and archae-bacteria (a group of ancient bacteria).

input.question: In five kingdom system, the main basis of classification is

response.explanation: The five kingdom classification is based on complexity of cell structure, complexity of body structure, modes of nutrition, ecological life styles, and phylogenetic relationship.

input.question: A system of classification in which a large number of traits are considered, is

response.explanation: Artificial system of classification is based on comparison of one or a few characters. A system based upon a large number of natural characters or traits is natural system of classification.

input.question: Phylogenetic classification is based on

response.explanation: Phylogenetic system of classification indicates the evolutionary or phylogenetic relationship of organisms. Organisms are classified on the basis of evolutionary sequence and genetic relationship.

input.question: Artificial system of classification was first used by

response.explanation: Pliny the Elder introduced first artificial system of classification in his book Historia Naturalis. He classified both plants and animals.

input.question: System of classification used by Linnaeus was

response.explanation: Linnaeus put forward an 'Artificial system' of plant classification which was based on sexual characters. It is commonly also called as sexual system of plant classification.

input.question: Classification given by Bentham and Hooker is

response.explanation: George Bentham and Joseph Dalton Hooker have given Natural system of classification. In this system all the important characteristics of the organisms that provide information regarding their natural relationship are taken into consideration.

input.question: One scientist cultured Cladophora in a suspension of Azotobacter and illuminated the culture by splitting light through a prism. He observed that bacteria accumulated mainly in the region of:

response.explanation: Azotobacter is aerobic bacteria. Engelmann used a prism to split light and observed that aerobic bacteria accumulated mainly in the region of blue and red light of the split spectrum thus giving the first action spectrum of photosynthesis.

input.question: Match the organisms in column I with habitats in column II.

response.explanation: Halophiles live in salty areas. Thermoacidophiles are present in hot springs. Methanogens are present in gut of several ruminants. Cyanobacteria can be present in freshwater marine or terrestrial habitat.

input.question: Which among the following is not a prokaryote?

response.explanation: Saccharomyces i.e. yeast is an eukaryote (unicellular fungi). Mycobacterium is a bacterium. Oscillatoria and Nostoc are cyanobacteria.

input.question: Which of the following are found in extreme saline conditions?

response.explanation: Archaebacteria are able to survive in harsh conditions due to the presence of branched lipid chain in cell membrane that reduces fluidity of cell membrane. It includes halophiles which are exclusively found in saline habitats.

input.question: Which of the following components provides sticky character to the bacterial cell?

response.explanation: Sticky character of the bacterial wall is due to glycocalyx which is rich in glycoproteins.

input.question: Which among the following are the smallest living cells, known without a definite cell wall, pathogenic to plants as well as animals and can survive without oxygen?

response.explanation: Mycoplasmas are smallest, prokaryotes lacking cell wall and are pleomorphic in nature. These are pathogenic to both plants and animals.

input.question: Which of the following structures is not found in a prokaryotic cell?

response.explanation: Nuclear envelope is not found in a prokaryotic cell.

input.question: The structures that help some bacteria to attach to rocks and / or host tissues are:

response.explanation: Fimbriae assist some bacteria in attaching to rocks or host body for obtaining establishment and nutrition.

input.question: Archaebacteria differ from eubacteria in:

response.explanation: Archaebacteria differ from other bacteria in having a different cell wall structure. They lack peptidoglycan in cell wall and possess a monolayer of branched fatty acids attached to glycerol by ether bonds in their cell membranes.

input.question: The motile bacteria are able to move by:

response.explanation: Motile bacteria have thin filamentous extensions on their cell wall called flagella.

input.question: Which of the following are likely to be present in deep sea water?

response.explanation: Archaebacteria live in some of the most harsh habitats such as extreme salty areas (halophiles), hot springs (thermoacidophiles) and marshy areas (methanogens) and in deep sea water.

input.question: Specialized cells for fixing atmospheric nitrogen in Nostoc are

response.explanation: Heterocysts are large sized, thick-walled specialised cells which occur in terminal, intercalary or lateral position in filamentous cyanobacteria, e.g., Nostoc. They have enzyme nitrogenase and are specialised to perform biological nitrogen fixation.

input.question: The most abundant prokaryotes helpful to humans in making curd from milk and in production of antibiotics are the ones categorised as:

response.explanation: The most abundant prokaryotes helpful to humans in making curd from milk and in production of antibiotics are the heterotrophic bacteria. Lactobacillus bacteria convert milk into curd.

input.question: The cyanobacteria are also referred to as

response.explanation: Cyanobacteria are also referred as blue green algae, they perform oxygenic photosynthesis.

input.question: How many organisms in the list given below are autotrophs?

response.explanation: Autotrophs are those organisms that are able to make energy-containing organic molecules from inorganic raw material by using basic sunlight.

input.question: Organisms called methanogens are most abundant in a:

response.explanation: Methanogens are archaebacteria, abundant in cattle yard and paddy fields.

input.question: Bacterial leaf blight of rice is caused by a species of

response.explanation: Bacterial leaf blight of rice is caused by a species of Xanthomonas. Mature rice plant are infected by these bacteria.

input.question: In the light of recent classification of living organisms into three domains of life (bacteria, archaea and eukarya), which one of the following statements is true about archaea?

options.a: Archaea resemble eukarya in all respects
options.b: Archaea have some novel features that are absent in other prokaryotes and eukaryotes
options.c: Archaea completely differ from both prokaryotes and eukaryotes

response.explanation: Archaea have some novel features that are absent in other prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

input.question: Thermococcus, Methanococcus and Methanobacterium exemplify:

options.a: Archaebacteria that contain protein homologous to eukaryotic core histones
options.b: Archaebacteria that lack any histones resembling those found in eukaryotes but whose DNA is negatively supercoiled
options.c: Bacteria whose DNA is relaxed or positively supercoiled but which have a cytoskeleton as well as mitochondria
options.d: Bacteria that contain a cytoskeleton and ribosomes

response.explanation: Thermococcus, Methanococcus and Methanobacterium exemplify archaebacteria that contain protein homologous to eukaryotic core histones.

input.question: Which one of the following statements about mycoplasma is wrong?

response.explanation: Mycoplasma are not sensitive to penicillin.

input.question: In which of the animals dimorphic nucleus is found?

response.explanation: Paramecium has two types of nucleus, a larger macronucleus involved with the vegetative activities and a smaller involved with reproduction.

input.question: The most throughly studied fact of the known bacteria-plant interactions is the

options.a: cyanobacterial symbiosis with some aquatic ferns
options.b: gall formation on certain angiosperms by Agrobacterium
options.c: nodulation of Sesbania stems by nitrogen fixing bacteria
options.d: plant growth stimulation by phosphate-solubilising bacteria

response.explanation: This phenomenon has been successfully used in genetic engineering to produce disease resistant varieties of plants.

input.question: The chief advantage of encystment to an Amoeba is

options.a: the chance to get rid of accumulated waste products
options.b: the ability to survive during adverse physical conditions
options.c: the ability to live for sometime without ingesting food

response.explanation: Encystment enables the zygote to survive under adverse or unfavourable conditions wherein it lies dormant.

input.question: Which bacteria is utilized in gober gas plant?

response.explanation: Methanobacillus (methanogen) occurs in marshes and also in dung. It produces CH4 gas under anaerobic condition and is utilized in gobar gas plant.

input.question: Which statement is correct for bacterial transduction?

options.a: Transfer of some genes from one bacteria to another bacteria through virus
options.b: Transfer of genes from one bacteria to another bacteria by conjugation
options.d: Bacteria obtains its DNA from other external source

response.explanation: Transduction is virus mediated gene transfer in bacteria.

input.question: What is true for cyanobacteria?

response.explanation: Cyanobacteria are oxygenic photoautotroph. Many members perform nitrogen fixation.

input.question: What is true for archaebacteria?

response.explanation: Archaebacteria are the most ancient and halogenous group of bacteria and are called living fossils.

input.question: The main difference in Gram (+)ve and Gram (-)ve bacteria resides in their

response.explanation: Gram +(ve) and Gram â€“(ve) bacteria are separated on the basis of their cell wall composition.

input.question: Photosynthetic bacteria have pigments in

response.explanation: Chromatophores are internal membrane systems present in photosynthetic prokaryotes. These develop as membrane lined sacs or thylakoids from plasma membrane.

input.question: In prokaryotes, the genetic material is

response.explanation: In prokaryotes nucleoid consist of double stranded circular DNA without histone protein.

input.question: A few organisms are known to grow and multiply at temperatures of 100â€“105Â°C. They belong to

response.explanation: These are archaebacteria which can tolerate high temperature.

input.question: Transfer of genetic information from one bacterium to another in the transduction process is through

options.b: Bacteriophages released from the donor bacterial strain
options.d: Physical contact between donor and recipient strain

response.explanation: Transfer of genetic information from one bacterium to another by physical contact is called conjugation while if it takes place by some other medium like virus than it is called transduction.

input.question: The hereditary material present in the bacterium Escherichia coli is

response.explanation: In E.coli double stranded DNA is present.

input.question: Sex factor in bacteria is

response.explanation: Sex-factor or F-factor in bacteria results in high frequency conjugation. It allows bacteria to produce sex pilus necessary for conjugation.

input.question: Temperature tolerance of thermal blue-green algae is due to

response.explanation: Some of the blue green algae can tolerate extremes of temperature due to presence of gelatinous sheath, and compactness of protein molecules in protoplasm.

input.question: Nitrogen fixer soil organisms belong to

response.explanation: Only some bacteria and blue green algae (cyanobacteria) have the capacity to fix atmospheric nitrogen.

input.question: Entamoeba coli causes

response.explanation: Entamoeba coli is a non-pathogenic species of Entamoeba that frequently exists as a commensal parasite in the human gastrointestinal tract.

input.question: Escherichia coli is used extensively in biological research as it is

response.explanation: Escherichia coli lives as a symbiont in human intestine and is easily cultured.

input.question: Genophore/bacterial genome or nucleoid is made of

response.explanation: The bacterial genome/nucleoid is made of single circular double stranded DNA without histone protein as it is a prokaryotic organisms.

input.question: Bacteria lack alternation of generation because there is

response.explanation: In bacteria asexual reproduction through binary fission is the most common method of multiplication. Sexual reproduction which comprises of syngamy and meiosis is entirely absent.

input.question: Name the organisms which do not derive energy directly or indirectly from sun

response.explanation: Chemosynthetic bacteria do not require sunlight as a source of energy either directly or indirectly. The energy for the synthesis of food is obtained by the oxidation of certain inorganic substances present in the medium.

input.question: Which one belongs to monera?

response.explanation: Whittaker (1969) divided organisms into five kingdoms: Monera, Protista, Plantae, Fungi and Animalia. Kingdom Monera includes all prokaryotes â€“ Mycoplasma, bacteria, actinomycetes, blue-green algae, archaebacteria, methanogens. Escherichia is bacteria.

input.question: Which of the following organisms are known as chief producers in the oceans?

response.explanation: Diatoms are the chief producers in some oceans and in some seasons as they are the primary producers and the food chain in marine ecosystem depends on it.

input.question: Ciliates differ from all other protozoans in

options.b: having a contractile vacuole for removing excess water

response.explanation: Ciliates differs from other protozoans in having two types of nuclei. E.g., Paramecium have two types of nuclei i.e. macronucleus & micronucleus.

input.question: Chrysophytes, Euglenoids, Dinoflagellates and Slime moulds are included in the kingdom

response.explanation: All unicellular eukaryotic organism like diatoms, desmids (chrysophytes), euglenoids, dinoflagellates and slime mould are included in Protista.

input.question: In which group of organisms the cell walls form two thin overlapping shells which fit together?

response.explanation: In chrysophytes, the cell walls form two thin overlapping shells held together. The body of Diatoms appears like soap box due to overlapping shells.

input.question: In the five-kingdom classification, Chlamydomonas and Chlorella have been included in

response.explanation: Chlamydomonas & Chlorella have been included in algae. Algae are chlorophylls, thalloid avascular plants with no cellular differentiation. Algae belong to thallophyta of plant kingdom.

input.question: Which one of the following organisms is not an example of eukaryotic cells?

response.explanation: E. coli is a prokaryotic gram negative bacterium.

input.question: Single-celled eukaryotes are included in:

response.explanation: Single celled eukaryotes are included in protista. Protista includes all unicellular and colonial eukaryotes except green and red algae. It is also known as kingdom of unicellular eukaryotes.

input.question: Which one of the following is a slime mould?

response.explanation: Physarum polycephalum belongs to phylum Amoebozoa, infraphylum Mycetozoa, and class Myxogastrea. P. polycephalum, often referred to as the 'many-headed slime,' is a slime mold.

input.question: The thalloid body of a slime mould (Myxomycetes) is known as

response.explanation: The thalloid body of slime moulds is made up of multinucleated cell which lacks septa in between and hence it is a multinucleated single celled mass called plasmodium.

input.question: Auxopores and hormocysts are formed, respectively, by:

options.d: Several diatoms and a few cyanobacteria

response.explanation: Binary fission in diatoms reduces the size of most daughters which is corrected through the development of auxospores. In some filamentous cyanobacterial forms unisexual reproduction occurs by hormogonia (hormocysts).

input.question: In Amoeba and Paramecium osmoregulation occurs through

response.explanation: Contractile vacuole in Amoeba and Paramecium maintain the water balance of the cell. This is known as osmoregulation.

input.question: Which of the following organism possesses characteristics of both a plant and an animal?

response.explanation: The Euglena is an organism, which possesses both the characteristics of plants and animals, as it can move with a flagella and also contains chlorophyll. Its nutrition is mixotrophic.

input.question: The function of contractile vacuole, in protozoa, is

response.explanation: In protozoa, the function of contractile vacuole is the removal of excretory substances, carbon dioxide etc. It is very essential to regulate water content i.e., osmoregulation.

input.question: Macro and micronucleus are the characteristic feature of

response.explanation: The macronucleus lacks nuclear membrane and is formed of trophochromatin. It regulates the metabolic activities of the body. The micronucleus has a definite nuclear membrane and controls the reproductive activities of Paramecium and Vorticella.

input.question: Excretion in Amoeba occurs through

response.explanation: The contractile vacuole is supposed to assist excretion in Amoeba, as its watery contents possess traces of carbon dioxide and urea.

input.question: Protistan genome has

options.a: membrane bound nucleoproteins embedded in cytoplasm
options.c: gene containing nucleoproteins condensed together in loose mass
options.d: nucleoprotein in direct contact with cell substance

response.explanation: Protistans are eukaryotes and their genetic material is organised in form of nucleus. DNA is associated with histone protein.

input.question: Protists obtain food as

response.explanation: Members of Kingdom Protista have diverse mode of nutrition. They are photosynthetic, saprophytic, parasitic and ingestive. They are major heterotrophs.

input.question: Protista includes

response.explanation: Kingdom Protista includes flagellates (eugenophyceae), diatoms, dinoflagellates, slime moulds, sarcodines, ciliates, sporozoans. They have photosynthetic, chemotrophic, heterotropic mode of nutrition.

input.question: African sleeping sickness is due to

options.a: Plasmodium vivax transmitted by Tse tse fly
options.b: Trypanosoma lewsii transmitted by Bed Bug

response.explanation: Bryophytes are amphibians because they complete their vegetative phase on land but water is necessary for their reproductive phase.

input.question: Apophysis in the capsule of Funaria is

response.explanation: Capsule of Funaria is differentiated into: (1) Operculum â€“ upper part - forms lid (2) Theca â€“ Middle â€“ fertile part (3) Apophysis â€“ lower part -photosynthetic

input.question: Moss peristome takes part in

response.explanation: Peristome is a ring of tooth like structure around. These are in two rows and helps in the dispersal of the spores due to hygroscopic nature.

input.question: Sperms of both Funaria and Pteris were released together near the archegonia of Pteris. Only its sperms enter the archegonia as

options.b: Funaria sperms get killed by Pteris sperms
options.d: Pteris archegonia release chemical to attract its sperms

response.explanation: Archegonia of a particular species recognises antherozoids (sperms) of the same species through release of chemical. In Pteris, archegonia produces malic acid which attracts sperms of Pteris only for fertilization.

input.question: In bryophytes and pteridophytes, transport of male gametes requires

response.explanation: Bryophytes neither have pollen nor flowers and rely on water to carry the male gametes (sperm) to the female gametes (eggs). The antherozoids (male gametes of pteridophytes) are armed with hair-like or whip-like cilia or flagellate and are able to swim through water.

input.question: The plant body is thalloid in

response.explanation: The plant body of a liverwort is haploid (n), gametophytic, small, dorsoventrally flattened, thallose, dichotomously branched fixed by unicellular and unbranched rhizoids, e.g., Marchantia.

input.question: Selaginella and Salvinia are considered to represent a significant step towards evolution of seed habit because:

options.a: female gametophyte is free and gets dispersed like seeds
options.c: megaspores possess endosperm and embryo surrounded by seed coat
options.d: embryo develops in female gametophyte which is retained on parent sporophyte

response.explanation: Selaginella and Salvinia are advanced pteridophytes where embryo develops in female gametophyte which is retained on parent sporophyte.

input.question: In which one of the following, male and female gametophytes do not have free living independent existence?

response.explanation: Male and female gametophytes of Cedrus do not have free living independent existence. Cedrus belongs to conifer.

input.question: Which one of the following is heterosporous?

response.explanation: Salvinia is an heterosporous aquatic fern with both annual and perennial species. The heterosporous have two types of spores, microspores and megaspores.

input.question: In the prothallus of a vascular cryptogam, the antherozoids and eggs mature at different times. As a result

options.a: there is high degree of sterility
options.b: one can conclude that the plant is apomictic
options.d: there is no change in success rate of fertilization

response.explanation: In the prothallus of a vascular cryptogams the antherozoids and eggs mature at different times which result in failure of self-fertilisation.

input.question: In Ferns meiosis occurs when

response.explanation: Gametic meiosis is found in all animals. In sporic meiosis the sporophyte produces sporangia where as meiosis occurs producing haploid spores.

input.question: Dichotomous branching is found in

response.explanation: In mosses, branching is lateral but extra-axillary (Funaria). Marchantia is a dorsiventral dichotomously branched thalloid liverwort.

input.question: The 'walking' fern is so named because

options.a: it is dispersed through the agency of walking animals
options.b: it propagates vegetatively by its leaf tips
options.c: it knows how to walk by itself
options.d: its spores are able to walk

response.explanation: Vegetative reproduction occurs in ferns by fragmentation of rhizome and growth of adventitious buds. In Adiantum caudatum the adventitious buds occur at the leaf tips. Adiantum is also called the walking fern because of its ability to form new ferns whenever the leaf tip happens to come in contact with soil.

input.question: Multicellular branched rhizoids and leafy gametophytes are characteristic of

response.explanation: In pteridophytes, the gametophyte is independent living, small thalloid structure called prothallus. In pteridophytes, the primary roots are replaced by adventitious roots. Whereas in bryophytes, the gametophyte is leafy.

input.question: The 'amphibians' of plant kingdom are

options.d: pteridophytes with complex internal organization not reaching angiosperm level

response.explanation: Bryophytes are terrestrial plants but they require a thin film of water on the surface of their substratum during sexual reproduction, hence they are called amphibians of the plant kingdom.

input.question: Pteridophytes differ from mosses/bryophytes in possessing

response.explanation: Well developed vascular system is present in the members of Pteridophytes but absent in mosses as the plant body is sporophyte which is distinguished into true root, stem and leaves.

input.question: The plant group that produces spores and embryo but lacks vascular tissues and seeds is

response.explanation: Bryophytes are the plants which produces spores and embryo but no vascular tissues are present, although primitive type of conducting tissues are present in the form of hadrome and leptome.

input.question: Which one of the following is not common between Funaria and Selaginella?

response.explanation: Funaria, is a moss (Bryophyte) that possesses archegonium, embryo, flagellated sperms. These are also present in Selaginella (Pteridophyte) but it also has roots which are absent in Funaria.

input.question: Evolutionary important character of Selaginella is

response.explanation: Presence of two types of spores microspores and megaspores (heterospory) is the evolutionary characteristic feature in the life cycle of Selaginella.

input.question: Prothallus (gametophyte) gives rise to fern plant (sporophyte) without fertilization. It is

response.explanation: When prothallus of a fern gives rise to sporophyte directly from somatic cell without forming gametes it is apogamy. Such type of sporophyte is haploid in nature.

input.question: Which one of the following is considered important in the development of seed habit?

response.explanation: Heterospory is considered important in the development of seed habit. Heterospory was evolved from isospory independently by several plant groups in the Devonian period as part of the process of evolution of the timing of sex differentiation.

input.question: Plants reproducing by spores such as mosses and ferns are grouped under the general term

response.explanation: Plants reproducing by spores such as mosses and ferns are grouped under cryptogams.

input.question: Strobili or cones are found in

response.explanation: Strobili or cones are found in Equisetum.

input.question: Pinus seed cannot germinate and establish without fungal association. This is because:

options.b: it has obligate association with mycorrhizae
options.c: it has very hard seed coat
options.d: its seeds contain inhibitors that prevent germination

response.explanation: Pinus seed cannot germinate and establish without fungal association because it has obligate association with mycorrhizae.

input.question: Phloem in gymnosperms lacks:

options.d: Both sieve tubes and companion cells

response.explanation: Phloem in gymnosperms lacks both sieve tubes and companion cells.

input.question: Select the wrong statement:

options.a: Cell wall is present in members of Fungi and Plantae
options.c: Mitochondria are the powerhouse of the cell in all kingdoms except Monera
options.d: Pseudopodia are locomotory and feeding structures in Sporozoans

response.explanation: Pseudopodia are locomotory and feeding structures in Sporozoans is wrong statement.

input.question: Select the mismatch

response.explanation: Pinus is monoecious in which male & female cones are borne on different branches.

input.question: Select the correct statement:

options.a: Gymnosperms are both homosporous and heterosporous
options.b: Salvinia, Ginkgo and Pinus all are gymnosperms
options.c: Sequoia is one of the tallest trees
options.d: The leaves of gymnosperms are not well adapted to extremes of climate

response.explanation: Sequoia is one of the tallest trees is the correct statement.

input.question: In which of the following gametophyte is not independent free living?

response.explanation: Unlike bryophytes and pteridophytes, in gymnosperms the male and female gametophytes do not have an independent free-living existence. They remain within the sporangia retained on the sporophytes.

input.question: Read the following five statements (A to E) and select the option with all correct statements: (A) Mosses and Lichens are the first organisms to colonise a bare rock. (B) Selaginella is a homosporous pteridophyte (C) Coralloid roots in Cycas have VAM (D) Main plant body in bryophytes is gametophytic, whereas in pteridophytes it is sporophytic (E) In gymnosperms, male and female gametophytes are present within sporangia located on sporophyte

response.explanation: Statements A, D and E are correct: Mosses and Lichens are the first organisms to colonise a bare rock; Main plant body in bryophytes is gametophytic, whereas in pteridophytes it is sporophytic; In gymnosperms, male and female gametophytes are present within sporangia located on sporophyte.

input.question: Besides paddy fields cyanobacteria are also found inside vegetative part of:

response.explanation: Besides paddy fields cyanobacteria are also found inside vegetative part of Cycas.

input.question: Read the following statements (A-E) and answer the question which follows them. A. In liverworts, mosses and ferns gametophytes are free-living B. Gymnosperms and some ferns are heterosporous. C. Sexual reproduction in Fucus, Volvox and Albugo is oogamous D. The sporophyte in liverworts is more elaborate than that in mosses E. Both, Pinus and Marchantia are dioccious How many of the above statements are correct?

response.explanation: Three statements are correct: A, B and C are correct statements.

input.question: What is common in all the three, Funaria, Dryopteris and Ginkgo?

response.explanation: Presence of archegonia is common in all the three, Funaria, Dryopteris and Ginkgo.

input.question: Cycas and Adiantum resemble each other in having:

response.explanation: Cycas and Adiantum resemble each other in having motile sperms.

input.question: Which one of the following is a correct statement?

options.a: Pteridophyte gametophyte has a protonemal and leafy stage
options.b: In gymnosperms female gametophyte is free-living
options.c: Antheridiophores and archegoniophores are present in pteridophytes
options.d: Origin of seed habit can be traced in pteridophytes

response.explanation: Origin of seed habit can be traced in pteridophytes is the correct statement.

input.question: Read the following five statements (A - E) and answer the question. (A) In Equisetum the female gametophyte is retained on the parent sporophyte. (B) In Ginkgo male gametophyte is not independent. (C) The sporophyte in Riccia is more developed than that in Polytrichum. (D) Sexual reproduction in Volvox is isogamous. (E) The spores of slime molds lack cell walls. How many of the above statements are correct?

response.explanation: Two statements are correct: B and E are correct statements.

input.question: Which one of the following pairs is wrongly matched?

response.explanation: Ginkgo - Archegonia is wrongly matched as Ginkgo does not have archegonia.

input.question: Consider the following four statements whether they are correct or wrong? (A) The sporophyte in liverworts is more elaborate than that in mosses (B) Salvinia is heterosporous (C) The life cycle in all seed-bearing plants is diplomatic (D) In Pinus male and female cones are borne on different trees. The two wrong statements together are

response.explanation: The two wrong statements together are (A) and (D): The sporophyte in liverworts is not more elaborate than that in mosses, and in Pinus male and female cones are borne on the same tree (monoecious).

input.question: The gametophyte is not an independent, free living generation in:

response.explanation: The gametophyte is not an independent, free living generation in Pinus (gymnosperm).

input.question: Which one of the following plants is monoecious?

response.explanation: Pinus plant is monoecious i.e. both male and female cone are present in same plant but on different branches.

input.question: Which one of the following is a vascular cryptogam?

response.explanation: Equisetum is a vascular cryptogam. Equisetum is the only living genus in the Equisetaceae, a family of vascular plants that reproduce by spores rather than seeds.

input.question: Select one of the following pairs of important features distinguishing Gnetum from Cycas and Pinus and showing affinities with angiosperms

options.a: absence of resin duct and leaf venation
options.b: presence of vessel elements and absence of archegonia

response.explanation: The important features distinguishing Gnetum from Cycas and Pinus and showing affinities with angiosperms are presence of vessel elements and absence of archegonia.

input.question: Flagellated male gametes are present in all the three of which one of the following sets?

response.explanation: The male gametes of bryophytes are biflagellate and those of pteridophytes are multiflagellate, except Selaginella having biflagellates gametes. The male gametes of gymnosperms are non-motile except those of Cycas having multiciliate gametes.

input.question: In gymnosperms, the pollen chamber represents

options.a: a cavity in the ovule in which pollen grains are stored after pollination
options.b: an opening in the megagametophyte through which the pollen tube approaches the egg
options.c: the microsporangium in which pollen grains develop
options.d: a cell in the pollen grain in which the sperms are formed

response.explanation: In gymnosperms, the pollen chamber represents a cavity in the ovule in which pollen grains are stored after pollination within the pollen chamber.

input.question: Conifers differ from grasses in the

response.explanation: Conifers (Gymnosperms) differ from grasses (angiosperms) because in gymnosperms the female gametophyte is actually endosperm which is made before fertilisation.

input.question: Match items in Column I with those in Column II: Column I - (A) Peritrichous flagellation (B) Living fossil (C) Rhizophore (D) Smallest flowering plant (E) Largest perennial alga Column II - (J) Ginkgo (K) Macrocystis (L) Escherichia coli (M) Selaginella (N) Wolffia

response.explanation: Peritrichous flagellation: Escherichia coli; Living fossil: Ginkgo; Rhizophore: Selaginella; Smallest flowering plant: Wolffia; Largest perennial alga: Macrocystis

input.question: Which one of the following is a living fossil?

response.explanation: Cycas revoluta a native of China and Japan is commonly known as 'Tesso' or Sago palm. It is also called living fossil due to its primitive characters.

input.question: Which one of the following pairs of plants are not seed producers?

response.explanation: Pteridophytes (fern) and bryophytes (Funaria) are seedless plants. Gymnosperms (pines) and angiosperms (Ficus) are seed bearing plants.

input.question: Which one of the following is a living fossil?

response.explanation: Ginkgophyta is an ancient group, of which the sole living representative or living fossil is Ginkgo biloba or Maiden hair tree. It is native of South China.

input.question: Cycas has two cotyledons but not included in angiosperms because of

response.explanation: In Cycas (gymnosperm) the seed does not occur inside a fruit but lies naked or exposed on the surface of megasporophyll.

input.question: In which of the following would you place the plants having vascular tissue lacking seeds?

response.explanation: Pteridophytes are primitive seedless vascular plants. Bryophytes are non vascular embryophytes. Gymnosperms are seed plants.

input.question: Which one of the following statements about Cycas is incorrect?

options.a: It does not have a well-organized female flower
options.c: Its xylem is mainly composed of xylem vessels
options.d: Its roots contain some blue-green algae

response.explanation: In Cycas, conducting part of xylem consists of tracheids, not xylem vessels.

input.question: A well developed archegonium with neck consisting of 4-6 rows of neck canal cells, characterises

response.explanation: Archegonia is the female sex organ of bryophytes and pteridophytes. Its neck region is made up of 4-6 vertical rows of cells.

input.question: The 'wing' of Pinus seed is derived from

response.explanation: The upper surface of ovuliferous scale forms the membranous wings of the seed which helps in dispersal of the seed.

input.question: Which one is the most advanced from evolutionary point of view?

response.explanation: Pinus is a conifer, a member of gymnosperm has well developed conducting tissue and presence of seed, whereas Selaginella is a member of pteridophyte (heterospory), Funaria is a moss, Chlamydomonas is an alga.

input.question: A plant in which sporophytic generation is represented by zygote

response.explanation: The plant body of Chlamydomonas is gametophyte (haploid). It reproduces asexually by zoospore formation and sexually by gametes. Gametes are isogametes which fuse to produce diploid zygote which is the only structure representing sporophytic generation.

input.question: A plant having seeds but lacking flowers and fruits belongs to

response.explanation: Gymnosperms are vascular land plants having naked ovules i.e., ovules are not enclosed in a ovary hence, flower is absent. Ovules after fertilisation produce naked seeds.

input.question: In Pinus, the pollen grain has 6 chromosomes then in its endosperm will have

response.explanation: Pollen grains are haploid (n). If haploid no. of chromosomes are 6 then endosperm will also have 6 chromosomes as it is formed before fertilisation and is haploid.

input.question: Resin and turpentine are obtained from

response.explanation: Pinus species â†’ Resins and turpentine; Cedrus â†’ Timber for railway sleepers; Abies â†’ Paper, Canada balsam; Cycas â†’ Ornamental plant

input.question: In Pinus/gymnosperms, the haploid structure are

response.explanation: Pinus and in all other gymnosperms endosperm produced before fertilization and is haploid. Megaspore and pollen grain are initial structures of female gametophyte and male gametophyte respectively hence, they are haploid.

input.question: In gymnosperms like Pinus and Cycas, the endosperm is

response.explanation: In gymnosperms like Cycas/Pinus, endosperms of female gametophyte is haploid and formed before fertilisation. In angiosperms, endosperm is triploid and develops after fertilisation.

input.question: Double fertilization is exhibited by:

response.explanation: Double fertilisation is a unique feature exhibited only by angiosperms. It involves both syngamy and triple fusion.

input.question: Male gametophyte in angiosperms produces:

options.b: Single sperm and two vegetative cells
options.d: Two sperms and a vegetative cell

response.explanation: Two sperms and a vegetative cell are produced by male gametophyte in angiosperms.

input.question: In angiosperms, microsporogenesis and megasporogenesis:

response.explanation: In meiosis, the number of chromosomes are reduced by half producing haploid daughter cells. The microscope mother cell and the megaspore mother cell undergo meiosis to produce haploid microspore and megaspore respectively.

input.question: In angiosperms, functional megaspore develops into

response.explanation: During megagametogenesis functional megaspore (mostly chalazal) gives rise to embryo sac. This is the mature female gametophyte generation.

input.question: Compared with the gametophytes of the bryophytes the gametophytes of vascular plant are

options.a: smaller but have larger sex organs
options.b: larger but have smaller sex organs
options.c: larger and have larger sex organs
options.d: smaller and have smaller sex organs

response.explanation: The gametophyte of bryophytes are smaller but have large sex organs.

input.question: Male and female gametophytes are independent and free-living in:

response.explanation: Sphagnum is a bryophyte in which male and female gametophytes are independent and free living. In Pinus (a gymnosperm), mustard and castor (angiosperms), the main plant body is sporophytic.

input.question: Which one of the following has haplontic life cycle?

response.explanation: Ustilago has a haplontic life cycle. This is a simplest and most primitive type of life cycle. The other pattern of life-cycle have originated from this type.

input.question: Which one pair of examples will correctly represent the grouping Spermatophyta according to one of the schemes of classifying plants?

response.explanation: Spermatophytes are the seed plants. They are the plants bearing seeds containing a dormant embryo. It includes gymnosperms and angiosperms. Ginkgo belongs to group gymnosperms and Pisum belongs to group angiosperms.

input.question: Which of the following plants produces seeds but not flowers?

response.explanation: Maize, mint and peepal are flowering plants or angiosperms but Pinus is a gymnosperm in which seeds are produced but flowers are not produced or seeds are not enclosed in flowers.

input.question: Which of the following is without exception in angiosperms?

response.explanation: Vesselless angiosperms are Wintera, Trochodendron etc. Secondary growth is absent in some angiosperms. Angiospermic plants are autotrophic in nutrition. But some angiosperms are heterotrophic in nutrition. Double fertilisation is characteristic of all angiosperms.

input.question: The largest ovules, largest male and female gametes and largest plants are found among

response.explanation: Egg of Cycas (Gymnosperms) and its nucleus are the largest in the plant kingdom. The sperms of Cycas are also the largest in the plant kingdom.

input.question: Largest sperms in the plant world are found in

response.explanation: The sperms of Cycas are the largest in the plant kingdom reaching a size of 300 mm. Egg of Cycas and its nucleus are also the largest in the plant kingdom.

input.question: Seed-habit first originated in

response.explanation: Seed habit originated in Cycadophiles or pteridosperms.

input.question: Sunken stomata is the characteristic feature of

response.explanation: Sunken stomata is the characteristic feature of xerophytes which help in reducing loss of water from leaf surface. These type of stomata are found in Oleander or pine.

input.question: Pinus differs from mango in having

response.explanation: Pinus is a member of gymnosperm in which ovules are not enclosed in the ovary i.e. naked seed, whereas mango is a typical angiosperm whose ovules are enclosed in ovary i.e., presence of fruit.

input.question: Turpentine is obtained from

response.explanation: Turpentine is extracted from the wood (xylem) of Pinus (Gymnosperm). Turpentine is a fluid obtained by the complex distillation of resin obtained from trees, mainly various species of pine (Pinus).

input.question: Which one has the largest gametophyte?

response.explanation: As one moves from thallophyta â†’ Bryophyta â†’ Pteridophyta â†’ Gymnosperm â†’ Angiosperms, there is reduction in the gametophyte and elaboration of sporophyte. Hence, moss has largest gametophyte.

input.question: Bilaterally symmetrical and acoelomate animals are exemplified by

response.explanation: Platyhelminthes are bilaterally symmetrical, triploblastic and acoelomate animals with organ level of organisation.

input.question: Which of the following animals are true coelomates with bilateral symmetry?

response.explanation: Annelids exhibit bilateral symmetry with metameric segmentation where external segments correspond to internal segments. Adult echinoderms are bilaterally symmetrical. Aschelminthes are pseudocoelomates and platyhelminthes are acoelomates.

input.question: Consider following features: (a) Organ system level of organisation (b) Bilateral symmetry (c) True coelomates with segmentation of body. Select the correct option of animal groups which possess all the above characteristics.

response.explanation: Organ system of organisation, bilateral symmetry and true coelomates with segmented body are found in annelid, arthropoda and chordates. In mollusca, the body is unsegmented.

input.question: Which of the following characteristics is mainly responsible for diversification of insects on land?

response.explanation: The exoskeleton of insects consists of chitinous cuticle. It gets hardened due to deposition of calcium. It prevents dessication and gives protection.

input.question: Metagenesis refers to:

options.a: Alteration of generation between asexual and sexual phases of an organisms
options.b: Occurrence of a drastic change in form during post-embryonic development
options.c: Presence of a segmented body and parthenogenetic mode of reproduction

response.explanation: Metagenesis is defined as alternation of generation found in phylum cnidaria (eg. Obelia). In this phenomenon one generation of an organism reproduces asexually, followed by a sexually reproducing generation.

input.question: Which one of the following have the highest number of species in nature?

response.explanation: In nature insects have the highest number of species (30 million). Fungi have 100,000, angiosperms have 260000 and birds have 10,000 species.

input.question: Radial symmetry is usually associated with

response.explanation: Radial Symmetry is usually associated with sedentary mode of life (e.g. cnidarians). It permits an animal to detect food or danger approaching from any side.

input.question: True coelom is the space lying between the alimentary canal and body wall enclosed by the layers of

options.b: endoderm on one side and ectoderm on the other
options.c: mesoderm on one side and ectoderm on the other

response.explanation: Coelom is a fluid filled space between body wall and alimentary canal which is lined by parietal peritoneum (mesoderm) on the outer side and visceral peritoneum (mesoderm) on the inner side.

input.question: The organisms attached to the substratum, generally, possess

options.b: one single opening of digestive canal
options.d: cilia on surface to create water current

response.explanation: The organisms, which are attached to substratum, generally, possess radial symmetry in all vertical planes.

input.question: Radial symmetry is often exhibited by animals having

response.explanation: In radial symmetry â€“ body is cut longitudinally through any radius into two equal halves. Present in sessile animals i.e. star fish that live in the sea bottom.

input.question: Coelom derived from blastocoel is known as

response.explanation: Coelom or body cavity, when derived from blastocoel is pseudocoelom as in nematodes, rotifers. In this type of cavity, mesoderm is lined by only one side i.e., towards the body wall. Schizocoel is true coelom derived from mesodermal segments.

input.question: Metamorphosis of insects is regulated through hormone

response.explanation: Metamorphosis of insects is regulated through ecdysone hormone. Ecdysone is a steroidal prohormone of the major insect molting hormone 20-hydroxyecdysone, which is secreted from the prothoracic glands.

input.question: Ecdysis is shedding of

response.explanation: Stratum corneum is the outermost, partially cornified layer of scale like cells. Small fragments of this layer are periodically shed off from the body known as ecdysis. The new layer is regularly formed by underlaying stratum germinativum.

input.question: In case of poriferans, the spongocoel is lined with flagellated cells called:

response.explanation: In poriferans (sponges) choanocytes (collar cells) form lining of spongocoel. Flagella present in collar cells provide circulation to water in water canal system.

input.question: Body having meshwork of cell, internal cavities lined with food filtering flagellated cells and indirect development are the characteristics of phylum.

response.explanation: The given characteristic features define the phylum porifera.

input.question: Select the Taxon mentioned that represents both marine and fresh water species:

response.explanation: Members of Ctenophora, Cephalochordata and Echinodermata are exclusively marine.

input.question: Which one of the following living organisms completely lacks a cell wall?

response.explanation: Gorgonia (sea-fan) is an animal. All animals lack cell wall. Gorgonia is a genus of soft corals, sea fans in the family Gorgoniidae.

input.question: Planaria possesses high capacity of:

response.explanation: Planaria is a flatworm which possesses a high capacity of regeneration.

input.question: Which one of the following groups of animals reproduces only by sexual means?

response.explanation: In Ctenophora, sexes are not separate. Reproduction takes place only by sexual means. In Cnidaria, which exist in both forms, polyps produce medusae asexually and medusae form the polyps sexually. Porifera (sponge) reproduce asexually by fragmentation and sexually by formation of gametes. Protozoans come under protista which reproduce asexually and sexually by cell fusion and zygote formation.

input.question: Which one of the following kinds of animals are triploblastic?

response.explanation: Triploblastic condition can be seen in flat worms. Ctenophores, sponges and corals are diploblastic.

input.question: Which one of the following groups of animals is bilaterally symmetrical and triploblastic?

response.explanation: Aschelminthes is bilaterally symmetrical and triploblastic. These are mostly aquatic, free living or parasitic. Their body is three layered which is ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm.

input.question: Ascaris is characterized by

options.a: absence of true coelom but presence of metamerism
options.b: presence of neither true coelom nor metamerism
options.c: presence of true coelom but absence of metamerism
options.d: presence of true coelom and metamerism (metamerisation)

response.explanation: Ascaris is a common parasite found in the large intestine of man. It is worldwide in distribution. The number of worms may be 500 or more in a single host. Ascaris is characterised by presence of neither true coelom nor metamerism.

input.question: From the following statements select the wrong one.

options.a: Prawn has two pairs of antennae
options.b: Nematocysts are characteristic of the Phylum Cnidaria
options.c: Millipedes have two pairs of appendages in each segment of the body
options.d: Animals belonging to Phylum Porifera are exclusively marine

response.explanation: Animals belonging to Phylum Porifera are mostly marine except a few which are found in fresh water- e.g. Spongilla, Euspongia.

input.question: In contrast to Annelids the Platyhelminths show:

response.explanation: Platyhelminthes includes flat worms. There is no body cavity. The animals are therefore acoelomates. Annelids also have bilateral symmetry. They are coelomate having a perivisceral cavity divided into compartments.

input.question: During its life-cycle, Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke) infects its intermediate host and primary host at the following larval stages respectively:

response.explanation: When in contact with water, the egg capsule form non feeding larva miracidium. Miracidium enters the body of snail to form sporocyst. The sporocyst develops into redia. Redia form cercaria and come out of snail. They get encysted forming metacercaria.

input.question: Sycon belongs to a group of animals, which are best described as

options.a: multicellular having tissue organization, but no body cavity

input.question: If the head of cockroach is removed, it may live for few days because

options.a: the cockroach does not have nervous system.
options.b: the head holds a small proportion of a nervous system while the rest is situated along the ventral part of its body.
options.c: the head holds a 1/3rd of a nervous system while the rest is situated along the dorsal part of its body.
options.d: the supra-oesophageal ganglia of the cockroach are situated in ventral part of abdomen.

response.explanation: Cockroaches breathe passively through a network of pipes connected to holes called spiracles along the length of their body. They are independent of blood circulation to move oxygen around and their body fluids are at a much lower pressure. The sensory input from the eyes and antennae, along with many other behaviours, are transmitted and handled by their brain such as running and reacting to touch, handled by 'mini brains' called ganglia in each body segment. A decapitated cockroach will eventually starve to death but this can still take few days.

response.explanation: A male shark possesses a pair of claspers which are inserted into a female shark's cloaca (an opening on the underside of the body) at the time of mating. Female sharks do not have claspers.

response.explanation: The arrangement of ovules inside the ovary of a flowering plant is called placentation. In marginal placentation, the ovule develop from a longitudinal suture where the margins of the ovary wall fuse. e.g., Pea, gram. In apical placentation a single ovule is born near the apex of the ovary. Here ovary is unilocular (Cannabis). In superficial placentation the ovary is unilocular simple or syncarpous e.g. Nymphaea.

input.question: Floral features are chiefly used in Angiosperms identification because

options.c: reproductive parts are more stable and conservative than vegetative parts
options.d: flowers are nice to work with

response.explanation: Reproductive parts (floral features) are more stable and conservative than vegetative parts, which exhibit changes due to the environmental factors quite readily. So floral features are more reliable.

input.question: Hypanthodium is

response.explanation: Hypanthodium is a special kind of inflorescence where the receptacle is usually fleshy and flask-shaped. e.g. Ficus. In angiosperms, a hypanthium or floral cup is a structure where basal portions of the calyx, the corolla, and the stamens form a cup-shaped tube.

input.question: Epipetalous stamens with free filaments and fused anthers occur in

response.explanation: Asteraceae possess five stamens with free filaments but anthers are united forming a tube around the style (syngenesious).

input.question: Coconut fruit is a:

response.explanation: Coconut fruit is a drupe. A drupe is a fleshy fruit with thin skin and central stone containing the seed.

input.question: The morphological nature of the edible part of coconut is:

response.explanation: The edible part of coconut is its endosperm. Coconut has double endosperm, liquid endosperm and cellular.

input.question: The coconut water from tender coconut represents

response.explanation: Coconut water is the clear liquid inside young green coconuts (fruits of the coconut palm). In early development, it serves as a suspension for the endosperm of the coconut during the nuclear phase of development. As growth continues, the endosperm matures into its cellular phase and deposits into the rind of the coconut meat.

input.question: Cotyledon of maize grain is called

response.explanation: The cotyledons are known as seed leaves, they are attached to the embryonic axis. Dicotyledons typically have two cotyledons and monocotyledons have only one cotyledon. The single shield-shaped cotyledon in grains known as scutellum.

input.question: Coconut water from a tender coconut is

options.b: Innermost layers of the seed coat

response.explanation: Coconut water is the free nuclear endosperm which is used.

input.question: Which one of the following fruits is parthenocarpic?

response.explanation: Parthenocarpic fruits (eg - banana) are produced without fertilization of ovule. Parthenogenesis is a natural form of asexual reproduction in which growth and development of embryos occur without fertilization by sperm.

input.question: The wheat grain has an embryo with one, large, shield-shaped cotyledon known as:

response.explanation: Scutellum is large, shield shaped cotyledon that helps in the absorption of nutrients from endosperm during germination.

input.question: Placenta and pericarp are both edible portions in:

input.question: Which one of the following statements is correct?

options.a: The seed in grasses is not endospermic.
options.c: A proteinaceous aleurone layer is present in maize grain.
options.d: A sterile pistil is called a staminode.

response.explanation: Generally, monocotyledonous seeds (e.g., grasses) are endospermic but some as in orchids are non-endospermic. Mango is a drupe fruit that develops from multicarpillary, syncarpous, superior ovary having one or many seeds. A sterile stamen is called a staminode. In monocots, outer covering of endosperm separates the embryo by a proteinous layer called aleurone layer.

input.question: An aggregate fruit is one which develops from:

response.explanation: Aggregate fruits (etacrio) develop from the multicarpillary apocarpous ovary. They are of following types; etacrio of follicles, etacrio of achenes, etacrio of berries, etacrio of drupes.

input.question: How many plants in the list given below have composite fruits that develop from an inflorescence: Walnut, poppy, radish, fig, pineapple, apple, tomato, mulberry

input.question: What would be the number of chromosomes of the aleurone cells of a plant with 42 chromosomes in its root tip cells?

response.explanation: Aleurone cells are the outer cell layer of the endosperm, usually only one cell thick in wheat and the only endosperm tissue alive at maturity. The cell layers of this layer are responsible for the de-novo synthesis of enzyme needed during germination. The chromosome number is 63 of a plant with 42 chromosome in its root tip cells.

input.question: In a cereal grain the single cotyledon of embryo is represented by

response.explanation: Single cotyledon of embryo in cereal grain is represented by scutellum. Coleoptile represents the covering of stem. Coleorrhiza represents the covering of root. The aril may create a fruit-like structure called a false-fruit and is produced by a few species of gymnosperms, notably the yews and related conifers in the families Taxaceae and Cephalotaxaceae.

input.question: The aleurone layer in maize grain is specially rich in

response.explanation: The aleurone layer in maize grain is specially rich in proteins. Aleurone is a protein found in the endosperm of many seeds. It forms the outermost layer of the seed coat in some grains. During seed germination, hydrolysis in the seed causes the aleurone cells to break down into amino acids.

input.question: Which one of the following is a true fruit?

response.explanation: The fruit is a mature or ripened ovary. When a fruit develops exclusively from the ovary, it is said to be true fruit. When in addition to the ovary, some other floral part also participates in the formation of fruits, then it is known as false fruit. Apple, pear, cashewnut, mulberry etc. are all false fruits.

input.question: Which part of the coconut produces coir?

response.explanation: Coir (Etymological origin: from Tamil and Malayalam - kayar - cord) is a coarse fibre extracted from the fibrous outer shell of a coconut. input.question: New Banana plants develop from

response.explanation: Each pseudostem produces a single bunch of bananas, before dying and are replaced by a new pseudostem. The base of the plant is a rhizome (known as a corm). Cultivated bananas are parthenocarpic, which makes them sterile and unable to produce viable seeds. Lacking seeds, another form of propagation is required. This involves removing and transplanting part of the underground stem (called a corm). Usually this is done by carefully removing a sucker with some roots intact.

Orchid seedlings are mycoheterotrophic in their early development. In some other species, such as coffee, the endosperm also does not develop. Instead the nucellus produces a nutritive tissue termed perisperm.
